children.text: Students will understand and demonstrate a sense of what numbers mean and how they are used. Students will be able to:
1. Demonstrate an understanding of what numbers mean (e.g., that the number 7 stands for a group of objects).

EXAMPLES
  • Show that 6 is larger than 3, using beans in a cup.
  • Explain different ways to make 263, using hundreds, tens, and ones.
2. Understand the many uses of numbers (e.g., prices, recipes, measurement, directions in play).

EXAMPLES
  • Show that 6 is larger than 3, using beans in a cup.
  • Explain different ways to make 263, using hundreds, tens, and ones.
3. Order, compare, read, group, and apply place value concepts to numbers up to 1,000.

EXAMPLES
  • Show that 6 is larger than 3, using beans in a cup.
  • Explain different ways to make 263, using hundreds, tens, and ones.
4. Determine reasonableness of results when working with quantities.

EXAMPLES
  • Show that 6 is larger than 3, using beans in a cup.
  • Explain different ways to make 263, using hundreds, tens, and ones.
1. Read, compare, order, classify, and explain whole numbers up to one million.

EXAMPLES
  • Using pattern blocks, represent equivalent fractions, such as 1/3, 2/6, 4/12
  • Show how three pizzas can be shared equally by four people.
2. Read, compare, order, classify, and explain simple fractions through tenths.

EXAMPLES
  • Using pattern blocks, represent equivalent fractions, such as 1/3, 2/6, 4/12
  • Show how three pizzas can be shared equally by four people.
3. Demonstrate knowledge of the meaning of decimals and integers and an understanding of how they may be used.

EXAMPLES
  • Using pattern blocks, represent equivalent fractions, such as 1/3, 2/6, 4/12
  • Show how three pizzas can be shared equally by four people.
1. Use numbers in a variety of equivalent and interchangeable forms (e.g., integer, fraction, decimal, percent, exponential, and scientific notation) in problem-solving.

EXAMPLES
  • Use integers to write a play-by-play description of a game (e.g., football, soccer, or golf).
  • Respond to the following in a journal: How can you get a smaller answer when you multiply? How can you get a larger answer when you divide?
  • Estimate a 15% tip for a meal costing $38.60.
2. Demonstrate understanding of the relationships among the basic arithmetic operations on different types of numbers.

EXAMPLES
  • Use integers to write a play-by-play description of a game (e.g., football, soccer, or golf).
  • Respond to the following in a journal: How can you get a smaller answer when you multiply? How can you get a larger answer when you divide?
  • Estimate a 15% tip for a meal costing $38.60.
3. Apply concepts of ratios, proportions, percents, and number theory (e.g., primes, factors, and multiples) in practical and other mathematical situations.

EXAMPLES
  • Use integers to write a play-by-play description of a game (e.g., football, soccer, or golf).
  • Respond to the following in a journal: How can you get a smaller answer when you multiply? How can you get a larger answer when you divide?
  • Estimate a 15% tip for a meal costing $38.60.
4. Represent numerical relationships in graphs, tables, and charts.

EXAMPLES
  • Use integers to write a play-by-play description of a game (e.g., football, soccer, or golf).
  • Respond to the following in a journal: How can you get a smaller answer when you multiply? How can you get a larger answer when you divide?
  • Estimate a 15% tip for a meal costing $38.60.
1. Describe the structure of the real number system and identify its appropriate applications and limitations.

EXAMPLE
  • Given two numbers such as 1/2 and 1/3, describe the real numbers between them.
2. Explain what complex numbers (real and imaginary) mean and describe some of their many uses.

EXAMPLE
  • Given two numbers such as 1/2 and 1/3, describe the real numbers between them.
Students will understand and demonstrate computation skills. Students will be able to:
1. Use and apply estimation with quantities, measurements, computations, and problem-solving.

EXAMPLES
  • Estimate reasonably and count accurately the number of seeds in a container.
  • Solve a problem such as: we have 24 seats and 19 children. How many seats will be empty after all the children are in their chairs?
  • Show different coin combinations to make 75¢.
2. Use multiple strategies in solving problems involving addition and subtraction of whole numbers.

EXAMPLES
  • Estimate reasonably and count accurately the number of seeds in a container.
  • Solve a problem such as: we have 24 seats and 19 children. How many seats will be empty after all the children are in their chairs?
  • Show different coin combinations to make 75¢.
3. Show understanding of addition and subtraction by using a variety of materials, strategies, and symbols.

EXAMPLES
  • Estimate reasonably and count accurately the number of seeds in a container.
  • Solve a problem such as: we have 24 seats and 19 children. How many seats will be empty after all the children are in their chairs?
  • Show different coin combinations to make 75¢.
1. Solve multi-step, real-life problems using the four operations with whole numbers.

EXAMPLES
  • Solve problems such as finding the number of rectangular arrangements for 36 like objects
  • Organize a budget for a project.
2. Solve real-life problems involving addition and subtraction of simple fractions.

EXAMPLES
  • Solve problems such as finding the number of rectangular arrangements for 36 like objects
  • Organize a budget for a project.
3. Demonstrate and explain the problem-solving process using appropriate tools and technology and defend the reasonableness of results.

EXAMPLES
  • Solve problems such as finding the number of rectangular arrangements for 36 like objects
  • Organize a budget for a project.
4. Develop proficiency with the facts and algorithms of the four operations on whole numbers using mental math and a variety of materials, strategies, and technologies.

EXAMPLES
  • Solve problems such as finding the number of rectangular arrangements for 36 like objects
  • Organize a budget for a project.
1. Compute and model all four operations with whole numbers, fractions, decimals, sets of numbers, and percents, applying the proper order of operations.

EXAMPLES
  • Show that there must have been at least one misprint in a newspaper report on an election that reads:
    - Yes votes 13,657 (42%)
    - No votes 186,491 (58%)
    and suggest two specific places a misprint may have occurred.
  • On a number line, name teh point located midway between 1/4 and 6.
2. Create, solve, and justify the solution for multi-step, real-life problems including those with ratio and proportion.

EXAMPLES
  • Show that there must have been at least one misprint in a newspaper report on an election that reads:
    - Yes votes 13,657 (42%)
    - No votes 186,491 (58%)
    and suggest two specific places a misprint may have occurred.
  • On a number line, name teh point located midway between 1/4 and 6.
1. Use various techniques to approximate solutions, determine the reasonableness of answers, and justify the results.

EXAMPLES
  • If 10% of U.S. citizens have a certain trait, and four out of five with the trait are men, determine what proportion of men have the trait and what proportion of women have the trait. Explain whether the answer depends on the proportion of U.S. citizens who are women, and if so, how?
2. Explain operations with number systems other than base ten.

EXAMPLES
  • If 10% of U.S. citizens have a certain trait, and four out of five with the trait are men, determine what proportion of men have the trait and what proportion of women have the trait. Explain whether the answer depends on the proportion of U.S. citizens who are women, and if so, how?
Students will understand and apply concepts of data analysis.  Students will be able to:
1. Formulate and solve problems by collecting, arranging, and interpreting data.

EXAMPLE
  • Make a graph to represent the number of family members for students in the class and use this graph to determine the amount of refreshments needed for a family-night out.
2. Make tallies and graphs of information gathered from immediate surroundings.

EXAMPLE
  • Make a graph to represent the number of family members for students in the class and use this graph to determine the amount of refreshments needed for a family-night out.
1. Make generalizations and draw conclusions using various types of graphs, charts, and tables.

EXAMPLE
  • Predict the number of buttons per student in the room. Collect data on the number of buttons for each student in the room, display the data on a line plot, and analyze it to determine the average number of buttons per student.
2. Read and interpret displays of data.

EXAMPLE
  • Predict the number of buttons per student in the room. Collect data on the number of buttons for each student in the room, display the data on a line plot, and analyze it to determine the average number of buttons per student.
1. Organize and analyze data using mean, median, mode, and range.

EXAMPLES
  • Conduct an experiment to determine the effects of fertilizer on plant growth, recording and analyzing information on charts and graphs.
  • Using the height of students in the room, calculate the mean, median, mode, and range.
2. Assemble data and use matrices to formulate and solve problems.

EXAMPLES
  • Conduct an experiment to determine the effects of fertilizer on plant growth, recording and analyzing information on charts and graphs.
  • Using the height of students in the room, calculate the mean, median, mode, and range.
3. Construct inferences and convincing arguments based on data.

EXAMPLES
  • Conduct an experiment to determine the effects of fertilizer on plant growth, recording and analyzing information on charts and graphs.
  • Using the height of students in the room, calculate the mean, median, mode, and range.
1. Determine and evaluate the effect of variables on the results of data collection.

EXAMPLES
  • Draw a scatterplot of the height of each student in the class vs. their shoe length and find the line of best fit using a graphics calculator or computer software.
  • Design and conduct an experiment to estimate the population of clams in a given clam flat.
2. Predict and draw conclusions from charts, tables, and graphs that summarize data from practical situations.

EXAMPLES
  • Draw a scatterplot of the height of each student in the class vs. their shoe length and find the line of best fit using a graphics calculator or computer software.
  • Design and conduct an experiment to estimate the population of clams in a given clam flat.
3. Demonstrate an understanding of concepts of standard deviation and correlation and how they relate to data analysis.

EXAMPLES
  • Draw a scatterplot of the height of each student in the class vs. their shoe length and find the line of best fit using a graphics calculator or computer software.
  • Design and conduct an experiment to estimate the population of clams in a given clam flat.
4. Demonstrate an understanding of the idea of random sampling and recognition of its role in statistical claims and designs for data collection.

EXAMPLES
  • Draw a scatterplot of the height of each student in the class vs. their shoe length and find the line of best fit using a graphics calculator or computer software.
  • Design and conduct an experiment to estimate the population of clams in a given clam flat.
5. Revise studies to improve their validity (e.g., in terms of better sampling, better controls, or better data analysis techniques).

EXAMPLES
  • Draw a scatterplot of the height of each student in the class vs. their shoe length and find the line of best fit using a graphics calculator or computer software.
  • Design and conduct an experiment to estimate the population of clams in a given clam flat.
Students will understand and apply concepts of probability. Students will be able to:
1. Use concepts of chance and record outcomes of simple events.

EXAMPLE
  • Investigate the possible and likely outcomes when rolling a number cube.
1. Explain the concept of chance in predicting outcomes.

EXAMPLE
  • Determine the combinations that could occur when four coins are tossed, and predict which of the combinations would occur most often. Conduct an experiment to show how close the predictions are to actual events.
2. Estimate probability from a sample of observed outcomes and simulations.

EXAMPLE
  • Determine the combinations that could occur when four coins are tossed, and predict which of the combinations would occur most often. Conduct an experiment to show how close the predictions are to actual events.
1. Find the probability of simple events and make predictions by applying the theories of probability.

EXAMPLES
  • Develop and analyze games of chance for a school carnival.
  • Determine how many license plates are possible if the first two symbols are letters and the last four are numbers.
2. Explain the idea that probability can be represented as a fraction between and including zero and one.

EXAMPLES
  • Develop and analyze games of chance for a school carnival.
  • Determine how many license plates are possible if the first two symbols are letters and the last four are numbers.
3. Use simulations to estimate probabilities.

EXAMPLES
  • Develop and analyze games of chance for a school carnival.
  • Determine how many license plates are possible if the first two symbols are letters and the last four are numbers.
4. Find all possible combinations and arrangements involving a limited number of variables.

EXAMPLES
  • Develop and analyze games of chance for a school carnival.
  • Determine how many license plates are possible if the first two symbols are letters and the last four are numbers.
1. Find the probability of compound events and make predictions by applying probability theory.

EXAMPLE
  • Determine the probability that a 90% free throw shooter will make exactly one of his/her upcoming two free throws.
2. Create and interpret probability distributions.

EXAMPLE
  • Determine the probability that a 90% free throw shooter will make exactly one of his/her upcoming two free throws.
Students will understand and apply concepts from geometry.  Students will be able to:
1. Describe, model, and classify 2D shapes and selected 3D figures.

EXAMPLES
  • Find all the shapes you can make with five squares of the same size if the sides touch completely.
  • Create symmetrical designs with pattern blocks and indicate lines of symmetry.
2. Investigate and predict the results of combining, dividing, and changing 2D shapes.

EXAMPLES
  • Find all the shapes you can make with five squares of the same size if the sides touch completely.
  • Create symmetrical designs with pattern blocks and indicate lines of symmetry.
3. Use positional words to describe the relationship of two or more objects (e.g., over, under, beside, to the left).

EXAMPLES
  • Find all the shapes you can make with five squares of the same size if the sides touch completely.
  • Create symmetrical designs with pattern blocks and indicate lines of symmetry.
1. Describe, model, and classify shapes and figures using applicable properties.

EXAMPLES
  • Design a nine patch quilt in which each patch is a nine inch square. Squares, triangles, rectangles, and/or parallelograms can be used for the design of each square.
  • Create symmetrical designs with pattern blocks and indicate the lines of symmetry.
2. Experiment with shapes and figures to make generalizations regarding congruency, symmetry, and similarity.

EXAMPLES
  • Design a nine patch quilt in which each patch is a nine inch square. Squares, triangles, rectangles, and/or parallelograms can be used for the design of each square.
  • Create symmetrical designs with pattern blocks and indicate the lines of symmetry.
3. Use transformations such as slides, flips, and rotations.

EXAMPLES
  • Design a nine patch quilt in which each patch is a nine inch square. Squares, triangles, rectangles, and/or parallelograms can be used for the design of each square.
  • Create symmetrical designs with pattern blocks and indicate the lines of symmetry.
4. Use the properties of shapes and figures to describe the physical world.

EXAMPLES
  • Design a nine patch quilt in which each patch is a nine inch square. Squares, triangles, rectangles, and/or parallelograms can be used for the design of each square.
  • Create symmetrical designs with pattern blocks and indicate the lines of symmetry.
1. Compare, classify, and draw two dimensional shapes and three dimensional figures.

EXAMPLES
  • Collect magazine pictures of different styles of architecture and identify all the geometric figures and relationships seen in each building.
  • Display data with an accurately drawn and divided pie chart.
2. Apply geometric properties to represent and solve real-life problems involving regular and irregular shapes.

EXAMPLES
  • Collect magazine pictures of different styles of architecture and identify all the geometric figures and relationships seen in each building.
  • Display data with an accurately drawn and divided pie chart.
3. Use a coordinate system to define and locate position.

EXAMPLES
  • Collect magazine pictures of different styles of architecture and identify all the geometric figures and relationships seen in each building.
  • Display data with an accurately drawn and divided pie chart.
4. Use the appropriate geometric tools and measurements to draw and construct two and three dimensional figures.

EXAMPLES
  • Collect magazine pictures of different styles of architecture and identify all the geometric figures and relationships seen in each building.
  • Display data with an accurately drawn and divided pie chart.
1. Draw coordinate representations of geometric figures and their transformations.
2. Use inductive and deductive reasoning to explore and determine the properties of and relationships among geometric figures.
3. Apply trigonometry to problem situations involving triangles and periodic phenomena.
Students will understand and demonstrate measurement skills. Students will be able to:
1. Estimate and measure length, time, temperature, weight, and capacity.

EXAMPLE
  • Put five objects, such as books, rocks, or pumpkins, in rank order by weight, first by estimating and then by measuring exactly.
2. Identify and give the value of different coins.

EXAMPLE
  • Put five objects, such as books, rocks, or pumpkins, in rank order by weight, first by estimating and then by measuring exactly.
3. Select standard and non-standard tools for determining length, time, temperature, weight, and capacity, and use them to solve every day problems.

EXAMPLE
  • Put five objects, such as books, rocks, or pumpkins, in rank order by weight, first by estimating and then by measuring exactly.
1. Solve and justify solutions to real-life problems involving the measurement of time, length, area, perimeter, weight, temperature, mass, capacity, and volume.

EXAMPLES
  • Find all of the rectangular areas, measured in whole square inches, for a particular perimeter, such as 24 inches, and see if the same pattern of shapes holds for another perimeter.
  • Determine what time it is necessary to leave the house for the fifteen minute walk to the bus stop and 1-1/4 hour bus ride to the 7:30 concert. Explain the answer.
2. Select measuring tools and units of measurement that are appropriate for what is being measured.

EXAMPLES
  • Find all of the rectangular areas, measured in whole square inches, for a particular perimeter, such as 24 inches, and see if the same pattern of shapes holds for another perimeter.
  • Determine what time it is necessary to leave the house for the fifteen minute walk to the bus stop and 1-1/4 hour bus ride to the 7:30 concert. Explain the answer.
1. Demonstrate the structure and use of systems of measurement.

EXAMPLES
  • Calculate the rate of speed of a moving object after measuring the distance traveled and the elapsed time.
  • Examine areas that can be enclosed using 24 feet of fencing and figuring out the maximum area.
  • Calculate the volume and surface areas of cones and pyramids.
2. Develop and use concepts that can be measured directly, or indirectly (e.g., the concept of rate).

EXAMPLES
  • Calculate the rate of speed of a moving object after measuring the distance traveled and the elapsed time.
  • Examine areas that can be enclosed using 24 feet of fencing and figuring out the maximum area.
  • Calculate the volume and surface areas of cones and pyramids.
3. Demonstrate an understanding of length, area, volume, and the corresponding units, square units, and cubic units of measure.

EXAMPLES
  • Calculate the rate of speed of a moving object after measuring the distance traveled and the elapsed time.
  • Examine areas that can be enclosed using 24 feet of fencing and figuring out the maximum area.
  • Calculate the volume and surface areas of cones and pyramids.
1. Use measurement tools and units appropriately and recognize limitations in the precision of the measurement tools.

EXAMPLES
  • Discover and explore the distance formula using the Pythagorean Theorem.
  • Using generalizations, compare the formula for the area of an n-sided, regular polygon to the formula for the area of a circle.
2. Derive and use formulas for area, surface area, and volume of many types of figures.

EXAMPLES
  • Discover and explore the distance formula using the Pythagorean Theorem.
  • Using generalizations, compare the formula for the area of an n-sided, regular polygon to the formula for the area of a circle.
Students will understand that mathematics is the science of patterns, relationships, and functions. Students will be able to:
1. Recognize, describe, extend, copy, and create a wide variety of patterns.

EXAMPLES
  • Recognize and describe the inverse relationship between addition and subtraction, e.g. 3+__=7, __+3=7, 7-3=__, and 7-__=3.
  • Show how the letters "aab, aab, ...," can represent the pattern "metal, metal, plastic, ...,", "leaf, leaf, rock, ...," or many other patterns.
2. Explore the use of variables and open sentences to describe relationships.

EXAMPLES
  • Recognize and describe the inverse relationship between addition and subtraction, e.g. 3+__=7, __+3=7, 7-3=__, and 7-__=3.
  • Show how the letters "aab, aab, ...," can represent the pattern "metal, metal, plastic, ...,", "leaf, leaf, rock, ...," or many other patterns.
3. Represent and describe both geometric and numeric relationships.

EXAMPLES
  • Recognize and describe the inverse relationship between addition and subtraction, e.g. 3+__=7, __+3=7, 7-3=__, and 7-__=3.
  • Show how the letters "aab, aab, ...," can represent the pattern "metal, metal, plastic, ...,", "leaf, leaf, rock, ...," or many other patterns.
1. Use the patterns of numbers, geometry, and a variety of graphs to solve a problem.

EXAMPLE
  • Find, make, and describe linear patterns on the 99-chart, for example 4, 14, 24, 34.
2. Use variables and open sentences to express relationships.

EXAMPLE
  • Find, make, and describe linear patterns on the 99-chart, for example 4, 14, 24, 34.
1. Describe and represent relationships with tables, graphs, and equations.

EXAMPLES
  • Collect data on the cost of first class postage stamps for a one hundred year period of time and predict future costs for such stamps.
  • Determine the units digit (ones' place) of (3)78.
2. Analyze relationships to explain how a change in one quantity can result in a change in another.

EXAMPLES
  • Collect data on the cost of first class postage stamps for a one hundred year period of time and predict future costs for such stamps.
  • Determine the units digit (ones' place) of (3)78.
3. Use patterns and multiple representations to solve problems.

EXAMPLES
  • Collect data on the cost of first class postage stamps for a one hundred year period of time and predict future costs for such stamps.
  • Determine the units digit (ones' place) of (3)78.
1. Create a graph to represent a real-life situation and draw inferences from it.

EXAMPLES
  • Express the diameter of a circle as a function of its area and sketch a graph.
  • Determine which of two ways of rolling a 8.5"x11" piece of paper into a cylinder gives the greater volume and whether there is a way to get even greater volume using a sheet of paper with the same area but different shape.
2. Translate and solve a real-life problem using symbolic language.

EXAMPLES
  • Express the diameter of a circle as a function of its area and sketch a graph.
  • Determine which of two ways of rolling a 8.5"x11" piece of paper into a cylinder gives the greater volume and whether there is a way to get even greater volume using a sheet of paper with the same area but different shape.
3. Model phenomena using a variety of functions (linear, quadratic, exponential, trigonometric, etc.).

EXAMPLES
  • Express the diameter of a circle as a function of its area and sketch a graph.
  • Determine which of two ways of rolling a 8.5"x11" piece of paper into a cylinder gives the greater volume and whether there is a way to get even greater volume using a sheet of paper with the same area but different shape.
4. Identify a variety of situations explained by the same type of function.

EXAMPLES
  • Express the diameter of a circle as a function of its area and sketch a graph.
  • Determine which of two ways of rolling a 8.5"x11" piece of paper into a cylinder gives the greater volume and whether there is a way to get even greater volume using a sheet of paper with the same area but different shape.
Students will understand and apply algebraic concepts. Students will be able to:
1. Make drawings for problem situations and mathematical expressions in which there is an unknown, using a variety of tools and approaches.

EXAMPLE
  • Show all the ways to make 10 (e.g., 2 + x = 10, 3 + x = 10, and so forth) by using blocks or other objects to demonstrate the mathematical statements.
2. Use language and symbols to express numerical and other relationships.

EXAMPLE
  • Show all the ways to make 10 (e.g., 2 + x = 10, 3 + x = 10, and so forth) by using blocks or other objects to demonstrate the mathematical statements.
1. Develop and evaluate simple formulas in problem-solving contexts.

EXAMPLE
  • Plot points on a coordinate graph according to the convention that (x,y) refers to the intersection of a given vertical line and a given horizontal line.
2. Find replacements for variables that make simple number sentences true.

EXAMPLE
  • Plot points on a coordinate graph according to the convention that (x,y) refers to the intersection of a given vertical line and a given horizontal line.
1. Use the concepts of variables and expressions.

EXAMPLES
  • Study the steepness of wheelchair ramps and stairs.
  • Solve for x: 3x - 5 = 23 - x.
2. Solve linear equations using concrete, informal, and formal methods which apply the order of operations.

EXAMPLES
  • Study the steepness of wheelchair ramps and stairs.
  • Solve for x: 3x - 5 = 23 - x.
3. Analyze tables and graphs to identify properties and relationships in a practical context.

EXAMPLES
  • Study the steepness of wheelchair ramps and stairs.
  • Solve for x: 3x - 5 = 23 - x.
4. Use graphs to represent two-variable equations.

EXAMPLES
  • Study the steepness of wheelchair ramps and stairs.
  • Solve for x: 3x - 5 = 23 - x.
5. Demonstrate an understanding of inequalities and non-linear equations.

EXAMPLES
  • Study the steepness of wheelchair ramps and stairs.
  • Solve for x: 3x - 5 = 23 - x.
6. Find solutions for unknown quantities in linear equations and in simple equations and inequalities.

EXAMPLES
  • Study the steepness of wheelchair ramps and stairs.
  • Solve for x: 3x - 5 = 23 - x.
1. Use tables, graphs, and spreadsheets to interpret expressions, equations, and inequalities.

EXAMPLES
  • Use measurements from shopping carts which are nested together to find a formula for the number of carts that will fit in a given space and a formula for the amount of space needed for a given number of carts.
  • Solve the following problem: Given the formula for height of an object thrown upward with velocity v: h = ho + vt + (1/2) gt², use quadratic functions and the quadratic formula to answer questions about the motion of projectiles and falling objects.
2. Investigate concepts of variation by using equations, graphs, and data collection.

EXAMPLES
  • Use measurements from shopping carts which are nested together to find a formula for the number of carts that will fit in a given space and a formula for the amount of space needed for a given number of carts.
  • Solve the following problem: Given the formula for height of an object thrown upward with velocity v: h = ho + vt + (1/2) gt², use quadratic functions and the quadratic formula to answer questions about the motion of projectiles and falling objects.
3. Formulate and solve equations and inequalities.

EXAMPLES
  • Use measurements from shopping carts which are nested together to find a formula for the number of carts that will fit in a given space and a formula for the amount of space needed for a given number of carts.
  • Solve the following problem: Given the formula for height of an object thrown upward with velocity v: h = ho + vt + (1/2) gt², use quadratic functions and the quadratic formula to answer questions about the motion of projectiles and falling objects.
4. Analyze and explain situations using symbolic representations.

EXAMPLES
  • Use measurements from shopping carts which are nested together to find a formula for the number of carts that will fit in a given space and a formula for the amount of space needed for a given number of carts.
  • Solve the following problem: Given the formula for height of an object thrown upward with velocity v: h = ho + vt + (1/2) gt², use quadratic functions and the quadratic formula to answer questions about the motion of projectiles and falling objects.
Students will understand and apply concepts in discrete mathematics. Students will be able to:
1. Classify sets of objects into two or more groups using their attributes.

EXAMPLES
  • Sort sets of tiles by color, size, and shape.
  • Determine the possible arrangements for a triple ice cream cone given three flavors of ice cream.
2. Create and use an organized list to determine possible outcomes or solve problems.

EXAMPLES
  • Sort sets of tiles by color, size, and shape.
  • Determine the possible arrangements for a triple ice cream cone given three flavors of ice cream.
1. Create and use organized lists, tree diagrams, Venn diagrams, and networks.

EXAMPLE
  • Use a Venn diagram to record the correlation between students who wore a sweater to school and students who walked to school.
2. Give examples of infinite and finite solutions.

EXAMPLE
  • Use a Venn diagram to record the correlation between students who wore a sweater to school and students who walked to school.
1. Create and use networks to explain practical situations or solve problems.

EXAMPLE
  • Use graphs and matrices to determine delivery routes from Augusta to other major cities in Maine with a combination of one way and round-trip routes.
2. Identify patterns in the world and express these patterns with rules.

EXAMPLE
  • Use graphs and matrices to determine delivery routes from Augusta to other major cities in Maine with a combination of one way and round-trip routes.
1. Use linear programming to find optimal solutions to a system.

EXAMPLE
  • Given a decreasing linear relationship between the selling price of a magazine and the number of people who will buy it, and given a fixed cost per copy that goes to production, analyze the profitability of the product and recommend a price range.
2. Use networks to find solutions to problems.

EXAMPLE
  • Given a decreasing linear relationship between the selling price of a magazine and the number of people who will buy it, and given a fixed cost per copy that goes to production, analyze the profitability of the product and recommend a price range.
3. Apply strategies from game theory to problem-solving situations.

EXAMPLE
  • Given a decreasing linear relationship between the selling price of a magazine and the number of people who will buy it, and given a fixed cost per copy that goes to production, analyze the profitability of the product and recommend a price range.
4. Use matrices as tools to interpret and solve problems.

EXAMPLE
  • Given a decreasing linear relationship between the selling price of a magazine and the number of people who will buy it, and given a fixed cost per copy that goes to production, analyze the profitability of the product and recommend a price range.
Students will understand and apply concepts of mathematical reasoning. Students will be able to:
1. Describe a simple argument's strengths and weaknesses.

EXAMPLE
  • Solve a simple word problem by finding and using the relevant information (Jack has 3 red marbles, 2 green marbles, and 4 toy cars. How many marbles does he have? 3+2=5.)
2. Distinguish between "important" and "unimportant" mathematical information.

EXAMPLE
  • Solve a simple word problem by finding and using the relevant information (Jack has 3 red marbles, 2 green marbles, and 4 toy cars. How many marbles does he have? 3+2=5.)
1. Demonstrate an understanding that support for a claim should be based on evidence of various types (e.g., from logical processes, from measurement, or from observation and experimentation).

EXAMPLE
  • Using data from the classroom and the entire school, prepare a report, including graphs, charts, and diagrams, on the optimal number and location of recycling containers.
1. Support reasoning by using models, known facts, properties, and relationships.

EXAMPLE
  • Prepare proposals for a fixed-height bridge and a draw bridge. Make recommendations after considering total cost, steepness of incline, traffic patterns, time of construction, etc.
2. Demonstrate that multiple paths to a conclusion may exist.

EXAMPLE
  • Prepare proposals for a fixed-height bridge and a draw bridge. Make recommendations after considering total cost, steepness of incline, traffic patterns, time of construction, etc.
1. Analyze situations where more than one logical conclusion can be drawn from data presented.

EXAMPLE
  • Given information about travel patterns in a local community, develop a convincing proposal for the logical placement of a bypass.
Students will reflect upon and clarify their understanding of mathematical ideas and relationships. Students will be able to:
1. Use numerals and symbols (>, <, =, +, -) to report numerical data and relationships.
1. Use simple tables and graphs to communicate ideas and information in presentations in a concise and clear manner.
1. Translate relationships into algebraic notation.
2. Use statistics, tables, and graphs to communicate ideas and information in convincing presentations and analyze presentations of others for bias or deceptive presentation.
1. Restate, create, and use definitions in mathematics to express understanding, classify figures, and determine the truth of a proposition or argument.

EXAMPLES
  • Having read the definition of "kite", a student analyzes a collection of figures to decide which are kites. The student then proceeds to apply the kite definition to the families of quadrilaterals to determine which are kites and why.
  • Student reads a manual or math text to successfully learn a new procedure.
2. Read mathematical presentations of topics within the Learning Results with understanding.

EXAMPLES
  • Having read the definition of "kite", a student analyzes a collection of figures to decide which are kites. The student then proceeds to apply the kite definition to the families of quadrilaterals to determine which are kites and why.
  • Student reads a manual or math text to successfully learn a new procedure.
